Award.AwardTitle: Interdisciplinary Coaching As a Nexus for transforming how institutions support undergraduates in STEM (iCAN)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A significant need exists to increase the number of STEM majors from underrepresented populations who are entering the STEM workforce. Nationally, fewer than 40% of undergraduates who intend to major in a STEM field complete a STEM degree. Traditional institutional reform efforts focus on system-level changes in instructor behaviors and supports. Unfortunately, current institutional reform efforts have not had an immediate wide-scale impact on the attrition rate of STEM majors. This project will examine how practicing in-service teachers can use mobile technologies to coach undergraduates in STEM majors who have executive functioning difficulties (e.g., higher order cognitive abilities such as planning, problem resolution, and mental flexibility) so that they can successfully complete introductory STEM coursework.

The "Interdisciplinary Coaching As a Nexus for Transforming how Institutions Support Undergraduates in STEM (iCAN)" is an exploratory project that will occur over two years. iCAN is a hybrid model of supports that relies on team coaching and mobile technologies (e.g., tablets & smartphones) to help undergraduates achieve executive function abilities that are critical to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) success. The project team will systematically investigate how a successful model for enhancing undergraduate STEM learning and persistence at Landmark, a small rural college in Vermont, can be migrated to the University of Central Florida, which is the second largest university in the United States. The project benefits both the graduate student teachers and undergraduate STEM majors. It also provides practicing teachers with insights regarding how to better prepare students to be successful in STEM majors at the undergraduate level. If this program proves as effective as expected, it will enhance STEM learning, persistence, and entry into the STEM workforce for all undergraduate students, particularly those with executive function deficits.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The iCAN study focused on undergraduate postsecondary students with disabilities in STEM majors at the University of Central Florida (UCF). Participants in the study had a disability related to executive functioning. Executive functions are defined as a dynamic network of higher order cognitive abilities (e.g., planning, response inhibition, problem resolution, working memory, and mental flexibility) supporting action toward a targeted goal (Barkley, 2012; Goldstein, Naglieri, Princiotta, & Otero, 2014). This decision to recognize executive function deficits as a category was the result of prior work funded by the National Science Foundation (Moon, Todd, Morton & Ivey, 2012). Participants in the study were registered with the Office of Student Accessibility Services. This registration provides documentation of a disability and promotes access to services such as extended time on tests, alternate test locations, and access to assistive technology.

 

Major goals of the project

            The iCAN project was an iterative exploratory investigation with multiple phases. Each was designed to allow us to answer two fundamental research questions related to STEM persistence and performance:

  1. Which attributes of the Landmark College model are most salient at a large urban institution?
  2. What technological and community supports add value to the model?

 

            Two hundred and seventy-four undergraduate STEM majors with disabilities at UCF completed the screening survey and expressed interest participating in the study. One hundred and twenty participated in the study with 60 in the treatment condition and 60 in control. The attrition rate for the study was 21%. There was a significant difference in Grade Point Average (GPA) between students in the treatment condition (M=3.23, SD=0.41) and the control (M=2.75, SD=1.18) condition; t(118)= -2.94, p = .004. In addition, there was a statistically significant difference in the number of students with disabilities who changed majors with students in the treatment condition (M=1.0, SD = 0.00) outperforming those in the control (M=1.13, SD= 0.34); t(118) = 3.01, p = .003.

 

            In order to confirm our results were generalizable to the broader population of individuals with disabilities in STEM majors at UCF, we conducted a five-year analysis (n= 35,021) of participation in STEM courses and majors by individuals across gender, race, disability status, first time in college, socio-economic status, and age. The rate of undergraduate participation in STEM majors was 3.6%. Results indicated disability status, race, and academic level had no effect on student’s GPA. In terms of STEM persistence, the project team disaggregated the results by race. Socio-economic status significantly moderated student’ persistence in a STEM major. More specifically, low-income, transfer students were more likely to change from a STEM major to a non-STEM. Students identifying as FTIC and low income were more likely to change from a STEM major to a non-STEM major.

 

            The project team developed a 16-item Qualtrics survey to identify the most beneficial community and technological attributes of the model. Findings from the survey and follow-up semi-structured interviews indicated students preferred face-to-face meetings with peer and career mentors and academic coaches. Participants expressed a desire for weekly meetings with academic coaches and monthly meetings with peer and career mentors. Effective instructional strategies included short and long term goal setting; study groups and sessions; assistive technology; visual scheduling; Cornell notes; and positive self-talk. The most successful coaching strategies included building trust relationships; active listening; mindfulness; cognitive reframing; positive reinforcement; and Growth mindset. Additional research is necessary to bolster evidence regarding a lower than expected affinity for networked communication within the coaching and mentoring cycle.

 


Last Modified: 07/13/2018
Modified by: Matthew Marino

Executive functions are defined as a dynamic network of higher order cognitive abilities (e.g., planning, response inhibition, problem resolution, working memory, and mental flexibility) supporting action toward a targeted goal (Barkley, 2012; Goldstein, Naglieri, Princiotta, & Otero, 2014). The project team developed a 16-item Qualtrics survey to identify the most beneficial community and technological attributes of the model.
